headline.main: New Federal Food Guide for Young Children Has Soft-Drink Makers in a Fizz

docs.abstract: Agriculture Dept issues its first guidelines on how to feed young children a nutritious diet, emphasizuing value of grains, fruits and vegetables; soft drink can that illustrates the recommendation that children should 'eat less' sugar in their diets outrages soda companies, which annually sell an average of 56.1 gallons of soda per person in United States (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: The Department of Agriculture yesterday issued its first guidelines on how to feed young children a nutritious diet, emphasizing the value of grains, fruits and vegetables. A soft drink can that illustrates the recommendation that children should ''eat less'' sugar in their diets has outraged the soda companies, which annually sell an average of 56.1 gallons of soda per person in the United States.

docs.abstract: Dr Sunil S Jhangiani leter on March 18 news article on link between chronic heartburn and risk of cancer of esophagus; contends it is no coincidence that 8 percent-a-year increase in esophagus cancer parallels similar increase in incidence of obesity in United States over last two decades
docs.lead_paragraph: To the Editor: A March 18 news article paints a grim picture of the link between chronic heartburn and the risk of cancer of the esophagus but does not mention the connection between obesity, chronic heartburn and cancer of the esophagus.
docs.snippet: To the Editor:    A March 18 news article paints a grim picture of the link between chronic heartburn and the risk of cancer of the esophagus but does not mention the connection between obesity, chronic heartburn and cancer of the esophagus.

headline.main: Early Eating Habits Tied to Adult Ills

docs.abstract: Two new studies lend support to view that by time children enter elementary school they may have eating and other health habits that will play a major role in problems they suffer in later life, including heart disease, high blood pressure and possibly diabetes; suggest that it is never too soon to teach children good dietary habits, as well as importance of exercise; this is especially true for black and Mexican-American children; one of studies shows that as early as age 6, they show significant health differences, over all, in comparison with non-Hispanic white children (M)
docs.lead_paragraph: Two new studies lend support to the view that by the time children enter elementary school they may have eating and other health habits that will play a major role in the problems they may suffer in later life, including heart disease, high blood pressure and possibly diabetes. Health experts said the findings suggested that it was never too soon to teach children good dietary habits, as well the importance of exercise. This is especially true for black and Mexican-American children. As early as age 6, one of the studies found, they show significant health differences, over all, in comparison with non-Hispanic white children.
